awd_abstract_narration:
A particle can spontaneously start spinning in an electric field, a phenomenon called Quincke rotation. This project will explore fundamentals and applications of electrorotation in fluid systems such as liquid droplets. The fluid-fluid interface can flow and the drop can deform, which creates a plethora of unexplained flow behaviors: a drop can tumble or beat like a heart, or small particles attached to the drop surface can cluster into vortices. The project will experimentally map electrorotational flows as a function of fluid properties and field strength. The experimental results will be used to develop models to elucidate the observed instabilities. In addition to advancing basic knowledge, the research will provide insights on how to harness these novel electrorotational flows for engineering of complex flows or of novel colloidal products such as patchy particles with dynamic surface patterns. At UCSD, the PI has been involved in engineering outreach to local high-school students, in the form of a summer course entitled "Introduction to Fluid Mechanics in Engineering: From a Straw to an Airplane." The results from this research can be folded into materials to support outreach of students"

The electrohydrodynamic flow about a leaky-dielectric liquid drop can undergo intriguing instabilities which involve generation of rotational flow, e.g., drop steady tilt or tumbling, or of vortices as previously observed on the surface of particle-coated drops. This project will establish the mechanisms of these electorotational fluid instabilities by developing (i) numerical simulations, based on the three-dimensional Boundary Integral Method, and (ii)  analytical models using asymptotic methods, of drop dynamics in electric fields. Experiments will be designed and carried out to guide and validate the computations and analytical results. The driving hypothesis is that electrorotational fluid instabilities are related to the Quincke effect (the spontaneous rotation of a particle in a uniform DC electric field occurring above a threshold field strength).  The research outcomes will lead to a much deeper understanding of the underlying physics as well as the discovery of new dynamical regimes and engineering opportunities. The potentially transformative nature of the proposal lies in the unexplained emergent behavior of the system that could inspire new research directions and applications related to complex fluids, instabilities and interfacial flows.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The interface between two liquids can be driven into motion and become unstable under the application of an electric field. In the case of a liquid droplet, this can manifest itself in a variety of ways, including: the emergence of internal flows, spontaneous rotation, and disintegration into smaller droplets via a variety of mechanisms. In the case of flat interfaces or liquid films, instabilities also arise, giving rise to spontaneous deformations, tip formation, and breakup into droplets. These phenomena are relevant to many technological processes and can be harnessed to produce droplets on demand, induce fluid mixing, or generate reproducible patterns, for example in manufacturing applications. The project funded by this award explored the fundamentals of electrically driven flows and instabilities in fluid systems involving interfaces, with the aim of elucidating the physical mechanisms giving rise to these complex dynamics. The project integrated theory, computations, and experiments, and transferred knowledge across the fields of fluid mechanics and applied mathematics to systematically investigate electrically-driven interfacial instabilities in fluid systems. The transformative nature of the project lies in the new understanding of emergent behaviors of these systems that could inspire new research directions and applications related to instabilities and pattern formation in multiphase fluids and interfacial flows.  At UCSD, the project trained one PhD student in theoretical fluid dynamics, complex fluids, scientific computing and applied mathematics. The research resulted in six publications in peer-reviewed journals, and the results were broadly disseminated by numerous presentations at conferences and invited talks.


Last Modified: 12/02/2021
Modified by: David Saintillan
